messageBody:
On 11/29/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
>
> I think it's like all problems. You can solve the problem directly or
> you can see if you can finesse it... that's when design goes deep and
> pays dividends. For instance, Steve Freeman has mentioned that the test
> prefix naming convention isn't really necessary in JUnit. You can just
> use reflection to pick up all of the methods on a test case class that
> accept and return void and treat them as tests.


I can share some experience about this...

In TestNG, you can declare a @Test annotation at the class level, and then
TestNG will automatically consider all public methods with void return types
of this class as tests. It saves a lot of typing and repetition (the DRY
principle at work).

It "kind of" works, but now and then, I still end up running methods that
are not really tests, which is, at best, harmless (it messes up your total
test count) and at worst, causes puzzling failures. It's still a useful
feature, but it absolutely has to be "opt-in" (the developer needs to
consciously put this annotation on the class).

I don't believe it's reasonable to make this the default behavior.

--
Cédric
